cot.content:
To solve the problem, Please think and reason step by step, then answer.
question:
In which film did Johnny Depp play a policeman called Ichabod Crane?
        
Generation Format:
Reasoning process:
Answer:

Reasoning process: 
To answer the question, I need to recall the films featuring Johnny Depp and identify the one where he plays a policeman named Ichabod Crane. Ichabod Crane is a character from Washington Irving's "The Legend of Sleepy Hollow." Johnny Depp portrayed this character in the film adaptation directed by Tim Burton. The film is known for its gothic style and unique interpretation of the classic story.

Answer: Sleepy Hollow

anchoring.content:
You are a cognitive scientist, to answer the following question:
In which film did Johnny Depp play a policeman called Ichabod Crane?
I will provide you with several retrieved passages:
Passages:
['BULLET::::- Johnny Depp as Ichabod Crane: Crane is a quirky, yet sympathetic constable infatuated with integrating modern science into police procedures, but is squeamish at the sight of blood and bugs. Depp is humorous in his portrayal of the character.\n', 'While Johnny Depp was Burton\'s first choice for the role of Ichabod Crane, Paramount required him to consider Brad Pitt, Liam Neeson and Daniel Day-Lewis. Depp was cast in July 1998 for his third collaboration with Burton. The actor wanted Ichabod to parallel Irving\'s description of the character in the short story. This included a long prosthetic snipe nose, huge ears, and elongated fingers. Paramount turned down his suggestions, and after Depp read Tom Stoppard\'s rewrite of the script, he was inspired to take the character even further. "I always thought of Ichabod as a very delicate, fragile person who was maybe a little too in touch with his feminine side, like a frightened little girl," Depp explained. He did not wish to portray the character as a typical action star would have, and instead took inspiration by Angela Lansbury\'s performance in "Death on the Nile". "It\'s good," Burton reasoned, "because I\'m not the greatest action director in the world, and he\'s not the greatest action star." Depp modeled Ichabod\'s detective personality from Basil Rathbone in the 1939 "Sherlock Holmes" film series. He also studied Roddy McDowall\'s acting for additional influence. Burton added that "the idea was to try to find an elegance in action of the kind that Christopher Lee or Peter Cushing or Vincent Price had." Christina Ricci, who worked with producer Scott Rudin on "The Addams Family", was cast as Katrina Van Tassel. "Sleepy Hollow" also reunited Burton with Jeffrey Jones (from "Beetlejuice" and "Ed Wood") as Reverend Steenwyck, Christopher Walken (Max Shreck in "Batman Returns") as the Hessian Horseman, Martin Landau ("Ed Wood") in a cameo role, and Hammer veteran Michael Gough (Alfred in Burton\'s "Batman" films), whom Burton tempted out of retirement. The Hammer influence was further confirmed by the casting of Christopher Lee in a small role as the Burgomaster who sends Crane to Sleepy Hollow.\n', 'BULLET::::- Constable Ichabod Crane serves as the protagonist in the 1999 film adaptation of "Sleepy Hollow", directed by Tim Burton and starring Johnny Depp. In this interpretation, he is a New York City policeman with an interest in Forensic science sent to Sleepy Hollow to investigate a series of grisly murders to prove the merits of his style of the investigation after he argues against the police\'s current methods. As in the original story, his horse is named Gunpowder. Ichabod\'s most notable traits in the movie include an ahead-of-his-time liking for post-mortem examinations, deduction, and scientific methods, as well as his being very quirky, skittish, and being disturbed by death and blood, despite his occupation. His backstory is also explored: when he was seven his mother, an "innocent child of Nature" was "murdered to save her soul" by his father, "a Bible black tyrant behind a mask of righteousness" which led to a loss of faith for him. It is Ichabod who finally releases the Hessian Headless Horseman (Christopher Walken) from the control of Lady van Tassel (Miranda Richardson), whom the Horseman takes to Hell with him. Katrina Van Tassel (Christina Ricci) is seen at the end of the movie going back to New York with Ichabod, along with a boy who helped him in the investigation. Brom Bones (Casper Van Dien), who at one point does disguise himself as the Horseman and throws a pumpkin at Ichabod, is killed by the real Horseman halfway in the film.\n', 'Depp\'s next venture with Burton was the period film "Sleepy Hollow" (1999), in which he played Ichabod Crane opposite Christina Ricci and Christopher Walken. For his performance, Depp took inspiration from Angela Lansbury, Roddy McDowall and Basil Rathbone. He stated that he "always thought of Ichabod as a very delicate, fragile person who was maybe a little too in touch with his feminine side, like a frightened little girl."\n', 'BULLET::::- Ichabod Crane is also featured in the 2013 episodic video game, "The Wolf Among Us", developed and produced by Telltale Games. In the game, Crane (voiced by Roger L. Jackson) is the deputy mayor of Fabletown, a secret community of magical, fairytale beings who were exiled from their Homelands centuries ago and forced to live in the world of mundane humans. In episodes 2 through three, Crane was revealed to have been soliciting prostitutes and using a magic spell to make them look like his assistant Snow White; Sheriff Bigby Wolf and Snow arrest Crane for this and embezzling Fabletown\'s money to pay for them, but Crane is then kidnapped by the minions of the Crooked Man, the crime lord Crane owes money to.\n', 'BULLET::::- Tom Mison as Ichabod Crane\n', 'BULLET::::- Tom Mison as Ichabod Crane\n', 'BULLET::::- Tom Mison as Ichabod Crane\n', 'BULLET::::- Tom Mison as Ichabod Crane\n', 'Jimmy Hunt, who plays the Police Chief in the 1986 version, played David MacLean in the 1953 film (renamed David "Gardner" in this version). David is seen watching this film\'s director Tobe Hooper\'s previous film, 1985\'s "Lifeforce", on television when his mother surprises him.\n']

Task Description:
Please extract content that may be unfamiliar to the model from these passages, 
which can provide the model with relevant background and unknown knowledge and concepts, 
helping it better understand the question. and analyze the role of these contents.

To answer the question about the film in which Johnny Depp played a policeman called Ichabod Crane, we can extract and analyze relevant content from the provided passages. Here’s a breakdown of the key information:

1. **Film Title and Release Year**:
   - The film is **"Sleepy Hollow,"** which was released in **1999**. This is crucial as it directly answers the question regarding the film's identity.

2. **Character Description**:
   - Ichabod Crane is portrayed as a **quirky and sympathetic constable** who is interested in integrating modern science into police procedures. He is characterized as **squeamish at the sight of blood and bugs**, which adds depth to his character and distinguishes him from typical action heroes. This characterization is important for understanding the nature of Depp's role and how it diverges from conventional portrayals of policemen in films.

3. **Plot Context**:
   - The film is a **reinterpretation of Washington Irving's story**, where Ichabod Crane is sent to **Sleepy Hollow** to investigate a series of grisly murders. This context provides insight into the narrative framework of the film and the motivations behind Ichabod's character, emphasizing his reliance on **forensic science** and **post-mortem examinations**.

4. **Character Backstory**:
   - Ichabod Crane's backstory includes a traumatic childhood event where his mother was murdered by his father. This detail enriches the character's psychological profile and explains his **loss of faith** and **sensitivity** to violence and death, which are central themes in the film.

5. **Director and Collaborators**:
   - The film was directed by **Tim Burton**, marking Depp's third collaboration with him. Understanding the director's style and previous works can provide context for the film's aesthetic and thematic choices, which often include gothic elements and quirky characters.

6. **Casting and Influences**:
   - The casting of **Christina Ricci** as Katrina Van Tassel and **Christopher Walken** as the Hessian Horseman is relevant as it highlights the film's ensemble and the dynamics between characters. Depp's inspiration from various actors for his portrayal of Ichabod adds layers to his performance, suggesting a deliberate effort to create a unique interpretation of the character.

7. **Cultural References**:
   - The mention of Ichabod's horse named **Gunpowder** and the character's traits being ahead of his time in terms of forensic investigation connects the film to broader cultural narratives about law enforcement and the evolution of detective work.

### Role of Extracted Content:
The extracted content serves multiple purposes:
- **Contextual Understanding**: It provides a comprehensive background on the film, character, and plot, which is essential for answering the question accurately.
- **Character Analysis**: The details about Ichabod Crane's personality and backstory allow for a deeper understanding of his motivations and the film's themes.
- **Cinematic Insight**: Information about the director and the film's production context helps situate "Sleepy Hollow" within Johnny Depp's career and Tim Burton's filmography, enriching the viewer's appreciation of the film's artistic choices.

In conclusion, the extracted content not only answers the question but also enhances the understanding of the film's narrative, character dynamics, and thematic depth, which are crucial for a well-rounded analysis of Johnny Depp's role as Ichabod Crane in "Sleepy Hollow."

The passages provided contain detailed information about Johnny Depp's portrayal of Ichabod Crane in the film "Sleepy Hollow," directed by Tim Burton and released in 1999. Here’s a summary and analysis of the key points:

1. **Character Overview**: Ichabod Crane, as portrayed by Johnny Depp, is depicted as a quirky and sympathetic constable from New York City. He is characterized by his interest in forensic science and modern investigative methods, which contrasts with the more traditional approaches of his contemporaries. His personality traits include being squeamish about blood and death, which adds a layer of complexity to his role as a policeman.

2. **Film Context**: "Sleepy Hollow" is an adaptation of Washington Irving's short story, and Depp's character is sent to the titular village to investigate a series of grisly murders. This plot element emphasizes the film's blend of horror and detective genres, showcasing Ichabod's struggle to reconcile his scientific inclinations with the supernatural elements he encounters.

3. **Character Development**: The film explores Ichabod's backstory, including a traumatic childhood experience involving his mother’s murder by his father. This backstory contributes to his fragile and delicate demeanor, which Depp aimed to portray authentically. Depp's interpretation of Ichabod Crane diverges from typical action hero tropes, focusing instead on vulnerability and emotional depth.

4. **Collaboration with Tim Burton**: This film marks Depp's third collaboration with director Tim Burton, and the creative process involved significant character development. Depp drew inspiration from various actors and performances, indicating a thoughtful approach to crafting his character. Burton's direction complements Depp's portrayal, as both sought to create a unique cinematic experience that emphasizes elegance in action rather than conventional heroism.

5. **Supporting Cast**: The film features notable actors such as Christina Ricci as Katrina Van Tassel and Christopher Walken as the Hessian Horseman, enriching the narrative and providing a dynamic interplay between characters. The casting choices reflect Burton's penchant for collaborating with familiar faces, enhancing the film's overall aesthetic and thematic coherence.

6. **Cultural Impact**: Depp's performance in "Sleepy Hollow" has been recognized for its originality and depth, contributing to the film's status as a cult classic. The character of Ichabod Crane has since been referenced and adapted in various media, indicating the lasting influence of Depp's interpretation.

In summary, the passages provide a comprehensive overview of Johnny Depp's role as Ichabod Crane in "Sleepy Hollow," highlighting the character's complexity, the film's narrative structure, and the collaborative efforts between Depp and Burton. This understanding deepens the model's knowledge of the film's context, character development, and the broader implications of Depp's performance in cinematic history.

To answer the question about which film features Johnny Depp as a policeman named Ichabod Crane, I will analyze the character and the film's context based on the retrieved passages. Ichabod Crane is a well-known character from Washington Irving's "The Legend of Sleepy Hollow," and Depp's portrayal in the 1999 film adaptation directed by Tim Burton is notable for its unique interpretation.

1. **Character Analysis**: In "Sleepy Hollow," Ichabod Crane is presented as a New York City constable who embodies a blend of modern forensic science and traditional detective work. His character is quirky and sympathetic, with a notable aversion to blood and death, which adds depth to his role as a policeman. This portrayal contrasts with typical depictions of law enforcement, emphasizing vulnerability and emotional complexity.

2. **Film Adaptation Context**: The film is a gothic horror adaptation that combines elements of mystery and supernatural themes. Depp's character is tasked with investigating a series of murders in the village of Sleepy Hollow, which allows for a narrative exploration of both rational investigation and the supernatural. This duality reflects the film's thematic depth and the character's internal conflict.

3. **Character Backstory**: The film delves into Ichabod's traumatic past, including the murder of his mother by his father, which shapes his character's psyche. This backstory not only informs his fears and quirks but also enhances the audience's understanding of his motivations and emotional struggles.

4. **Collaboration with Tim Burton**: Depp's collaboration with Burton is significant, as this film marks their third project together. Their creative synergy is evident in the film's stylistic choices and character development. Depp's approach to Ichabod Crane, influenced by various actors and performances, showcases a commitment to creating a nuanced character that defies conventional hero archetypes.

5. **Supporting Cast and Cultural Impact**: The film features a strong supporting cast, including Christina Ricci and Christopher Walken, which enriches the narrative and character dynamics. Depp's performance has been critically acclaimed, contributing to the film's status as a cult classic and influencing subsequent adaptations of the Ichabod Crane character in various media.

By synthesizing this information, I can confidently conclude that the film in which Johnny Depp plays a policeman named Ichabod Crane is "Sleepy Hollow." This understanding not only answers the question but also provides a deeper appreciation of the character's complexity and the film's artistic merits.

**Answer: Sleepy Hollow**

Burton added that "the idea was to try to find an elegance in action of the kind that Christopher Lee or Peter Cushing or Vincent Price had." Christina Ricci, who worked with producer Scott Rudin on "The Addams Family", was cast as Katrina Van Tassel. "Sleepy Hollow" also reunited Burton with Jeffrey Jones (from "Beetlejuice" and "Ed Wood") as Reverend Steenwyck, Christopher Walken (Max Shreck in "Batman Returns") as the Hessian Horseman, Martin Landau ("Ed Wood") in a cameo role, and Hammer veteran Michael Gough (Alfred in Burton's "Batman" films), whom Burton tempted out of retirement. The Hammer influence was further confirmed by the casting of Christopher Lee in a small role as the Burgomaster who sends Crane to Sleepy Hollow.
', 'BULLET::::- Constable Ichabod Crane serves as the protagonist in the 1999 film adaptation of "Sleepy Hollow", directed by Tim Burton and starring Johnny Depp. In this interpretation, he is a New York City policeman with an interest in Forensic science sent to Sleepy Hollow to investigate a series of grisly murders to prove the merits of his style of the investigation after he argues against the police's current methods. As in the original story, his horse is named Gunpowder. Ichabod's most notable traits in the movie include an ahead-of-his-time liking for post-mortem examinations, deduction, and scientific methods, as well as his being very quirky, skittish, and being disturbed by death and blood, despite his occupation. His backstory is also explored: when he was seven his mother, an "innocent child of Nature" was "murdered to save her soul" by his father, "a Bible black tyrant behind a mask of righteousness" which led to a loss of faith for him. It is Ichabod who finally releases the Hessian Headless Horseman (Christopher Walken) from the control of Lady van Tassel (Miranda Richardson), whom the Horseman takes to Hell with him. Katrina Van Tassel (Christina Ricci) is seen at the end of the movie going back to New York with Ichabod, along with a boy who helped him in the investigation. Brom Bones (Casper Van Dien), who at one point does disguise himself as the Horseman and throws a pumpkin at Ichabod, is killed by the real Horseman halfway in the film.
', 'Depp's next venture with Burton was the period film "Sleepy Hollow" (1999), in which he played Ichabod Crane opposite Christina Ricci and Christopher Walken. For his performance, Depp took inspiration from Angela Lansbury, Roddy McDowall and Basil Rathbone. He stated that he "always thought of Ichabod as a very delicate, fragile person who was maybe a little too in touch with his feminine side, like a frightened little girl."
', 'BULLET::::- Ichabod Crane is also featured in the 2013 episodic video game, "The Wolf Among Us", developed and produced by Telltale Games. In the game, Crane (voiced by Roger L. Jackson) is the deputy mayor of Fabletown, a secret community of magical, fairytale beings who were exiled from their Homelands centuries ago and forced to live in the world of mundane humans. In episodes 2 through three, Crane was revealed to have been soliciting prostitutes and using a magic spell to make them look like his assistant Snow White; Sheriff Bigby Wolf and Snow arrest Crane for this and embezzling Fabletown's money to pay for them, but Crane is then kidnapped by the minions of the Crooked Man, the crime lord Crane owes money to.
', 'BULLET::::- Tom Mison as Ichabod Crane
', 'BULLET::::- Tom Mison as Ichabod Crane
', 'BULLET::::- Tom Mison as Ichabod Crane
', 'BULLET::::- Tom Mison as Ichabod Crane
', 'Jimmy Hunt, who plays the Police Chief in the 1986 version, played David MacLean in the 1953 film (renamed David "Gardner" in this version). David is seen watching this film's director Tobe Hooper's previous film, 1985's "Lifeforce", on television when his mother surprises him.
']

Task Description:
Please extract content from these passages that can help enhance the model's causal reasoning and logical inference abilities.
consolidate these contents, and analyze how the selected information may impact the improvement of the model's causal reasoning and logical inference capabilities.

To enhance the model's causal reasoning and logical inference abilities, we can extract and consolidate relevant information from the provided passages regarding Johnny Depp's portrayal of Ichabod Crane in the film "Sleepy Hollow." Here’s a summary of the key points:

### Consolidated Information:

1. **Character Background**:
   - Ichabod Crane is portrayed as a quirky and sympathetic constable who integrates modern science into police procedures.
   - He is characterized by his squeamishness towards blood and bugs, which adds depth to his personality.
   - His backstory includes a traumatic childhood event where his mother was murdered by his father, leading to a loss of faith.

2. **Film Details**:
   - The film "Sleepy Hollow" was released in 1999 and directed by Tim Burton.
   - Depp's character is a New York City policeman sent to Sleepy Hollow to investigate a series of grisly murders.
   - Ichabod's investigative methods are ahead of his time, emphasizing post-mortem examinations and deduction.

3. **Character Development**:
   - Depp's portrayal of Ichabod Crane was influenced by various actors and performances, aiming to present him as delicate and fragile rather than a typical action hero.
   - The character's quirks and fears are integral to the narrative, affecting how he interacts with other characters and the unfolding events.

4. **Plot Elements**:
   - The film explores themes of fear, death, and the clash between modernity and superstition.
   - Ichabod Crane's journey involves confronting the supernatural, represented by the Hessian Headless Horseman.

### Analysis of Impact on Causal Reasoning and Logical Inference:

1. **Character Motivation and Behavior**:
   - Understanding Ichabod Crane's background and personality traits allows for better inference about his actions and decisions throughout the film. For instance, his fear of blood may influence his investigative approach, leading to moments of tension and conflict.

2. **Thematic Connections**:
   - The film's themes of modernity versus superstition can be analyzed through Ichabod's character. His reliance on scientific methods in a superstitious setting creates a causal relationship between his investigative style and the challenges he faces, enhancing the model's ability to draw connections between character traits and plot developments.

3. **Influence of External Factors**:
   - The character's interactions with other characters (e.g., Katrina Van Tassel, the Horseman) can be analyzed to understand how relationships and external pressures shape his decisions, further improving the model's ability to infer causality in complex narratives.

4. **Narrative Structure**:
   - By recognizing how Ichabod's character evolves in response to the events around him, the model can better understand narrative causality—how one event leads to another and how character development is intertwined with plot progression.

### Conclusion:

By consolidating and analyzing the information regarding Johnny Depp's portrayal of Ichabod Crane in "Sleepy Hollow," we can enhance the model's causal reasoning and logical inference capabilities. The insights into character motivations, thematic elements, and narrative structure provide a framework for understanding complex relationships within stories, ultimately improving the model's analytical skills in processing and interpreting narrative content.

Here is an answer generated by a language model with the reasoning process.
question:
In which film did Johnny Depp play a policeman called Ichabod Crane?
answer:
Reasoning process: 
To answer the question, I need to recall the films featuring Johnny Depp and identify the one where he plays a policeman named Ichabod Crane. Ichabod Crane is a character from Washington Irving's "The Legend of Sleepy Hollow." Johnny Depp portrayed this character in the film adaptation directed by Tim Burton. The film is known for its gothic style and unique interpretation of the classic story.

Answer: Sleepy Hollow

### Knowledge Enhanced Inference Process:

To answer the question about the film in which Johnny Depp plays a policeman named Ichabod Crane, I will follow a structured reasoning process that incorporates relevant knowledge about the character, the film, and its themes.

1. **Character Identification**:
   - Ichabod Crane is a character from Washington Irving's "The Legend of Sleepy Hollow." In the film adaptation, he is portrayed as a New York City policeman, which is a modern reinterpretation of the original character.

2. **Film Context**:
   - The film "Sleepy Hollow," directed by Tim Burton and released in 1999, features Johnny Depp in the role of Ichabod Crane. This adaptation is known for its gothic style and unique storytelling, which diverges from the traditional narrative.

3. **Character Traits and Development**:
   - Ichabod Crane is depicted as quirky and sympathetic, with a strong interest in forensic science. His character is marked by a fear of blood and bugs, which adds complexity to his role as a policeman. This fear influences his investigative methods and interactions with other characters, creating tension and conflict throughout the film.

4. **Plot Dynamics**:
   - The plot revolves around Ichabod's investigation of a series of grisly murders in Sleepy Hollow, where he confronts supernatural elements, particularly the Hessian Headless Horseman. His reliance on scientific methods in a superstitious environment highlights the clash between modernity and tradition, which is a central theme of the film.

5. **Causal Relationships**:
   - Ichabod's traumatic backstory, including the murder of his mother, shapes his character and motivations. This background informs his actions and decisions, allowing for a deeper understanding of his behavior throughout the film. The interplay between his character traits and the unfolding events illustrates how personal history can influence present actions.

6. **Thematic Analysis**:
   - The film explores themes of fear, death, and the struggle between rationality and superstition. Ichabod's character serves as a vehicle for these themes, as his scientific approach is constantly challenged by the supernatural occurrences he encounters.

By synthesizing this information, I can draw logical inferences about the film's narrative structure, character motivations, and thematic elements, enhancing the model's ability to understand causal relationships in storytelling.

### Answer:
Sleepy Hollow

Depp is humorous in his portrayal of the character.\n', 'While Johnny Depp was Burton\'s first choice for the role of Ichabod Crane, Paramount required him to consider Brad Pitt, Liam Neeson and Daniel Day-Lewis. Depp was cast in July 1998 for his third collaboration with Burton. The actor wanted Ichabod to parallel Irving\'s description of the character in the short story. This included a long prosthetic snipe nose, huge ears, and elongated fingers. Paramount turned down his suggestions, and after Depp read Tom Stoppard\'s rewrite of the script, he was inspired to take the character even further. "I always thought of Ichabod as a very delicate, fragile person who was maybe a little too in touch with his feminine side, like a frightened little girl," Depp explained. He did not wish to portray the character as a typical action star would have, and instead took inspiration by Angela Lansbury\'s performance in "Death on the Nile". "It\'s good," Burton reasoned, "because I\'m not the greatest action director in the world, and he\'s not the greatest action star." Depp modeled Ichabod\'s detective personality from Basil Rathbone in the 1939 "Sherlock Holmes" film series. He also studied Roddy McDowall\'s acting for additional influence. Burton added that "the idea was to try to find an elegance in action of the kind that Christopher Lee or Peter Cushing or Vincent Price had." Christina Ricci, who worked with producer Scott Rudin on "The Addams Family", was cast as Katrina Van Tassel. "Sleepy Hollow" also reunited Burton with Jeffrey Jones (from "Beetlejuice" and "Ed Wood") as Reverend Steenwyck, Christopher Walken (Max Shreck in "Batman Returns") as the Hessian Horseman, Martin Landau ("Ed Wood") in a cameo role, and Hammer veteran Michael Gough (Alfred in Burton\'s "Batman" films), whom Burton tempted out of retirement. As in the original story, his horse is named Gunpowder. Ichabod\'s most notable traits in the movie include an ahead-of-his-time liking for post-mortem examinations, deduction, and scientific methods, as well as his being very quirky, skittish, and being disturbed by death and blood, despite his occupation. His backstory is also explored: when he was seven his mother, an "innocent child of Nature" was "murdered to save her soul" by his father, "a Bible black tyrant behind a mask of righteousness" which led to a loss of faith for him. It is Ichabod who finally releases the Hessian Headless Horseman (Christopher Walken) from the control of Lady van Tassel (Miranda Richardson), whom the Horseman takes to Hell with him. Katrina Van Tassel (Christina Ricci) is seen at the end of the movie going back to New York with Ichabod, along with a boy who helped him in the investigation. Brom Bones (Casper Van Dien), who at one point does disguise himself as the Horseman and throws a pumpkin at Ichabod, is killed by the real Horseman halfway in the film.\n', 'Depp\'s next venture with Burton was the period film "Sleepy Hollow" (1999), in which he played Ichabod Crane opposite Christina Ricci and Christopher Walken. For his performance, Depp took inspiration from Angela Lansbury, Roddy McDowall and Basil Rathbone. He stated that he "always thought of Ichabod as a very delicate, fragile person who was maybe a little too in touch with his feminine side, like a frightened little girl."\n', 'BULLET::::- Ichabod Crane is also featured in the 2013 episodic video game, "The Wolf Among Us", developed and produced by Telltale Games. In the game, Crane (voiced by Roger L. Jackson) is the deputy mayor of Fabletown, a secret community of magical, fairytale beings who were exiled from their Homelands centuries ago and forced to live in the world of mundane humans. In episodes 2 through three, Crane was revealed to have been soliciting prostitutes and using a magic spell to make them look like his assistant Snow White; Sheriff Bigby Wolf and Snow arrest Crane for this and embezzling Fabletown\'s money to pay for them, but Crane is then kidnapped by the minions of the Crooked Man, the crime lord Crane owes money to.\n', 'BULLET::::- Tom Mison as Ichabod Crane\n', 'BULLET::::- Tom Mison as Ichabod Crane\n', 'BULLET::::- Tom Mison as Ichabod Crane\n', 'BULLET::::- Tom Mison as Ichabod Crane\n', 'Jimmy Hunt, who plays the Police Chief in the 1986 version, played David MacLean in the 1953 film (renamed David "Gardner" in this version). question_info.question: In which film did Johnny Depp play a policeman called Ichabod Crane?
passages:
BULLET::::- Johnny Depp as Ichabod Crane: Crane is a quirky, yet sympathetic constable infatuated with integrating modern science into police procedures, but is squeamish at the sight of blood and bugs. Depp is humorous in his portrayal of the character.
While Johnny Depp was Burton's first choice for the role of Ichabod Crane, Paramount required him to consider Brad Pitt, Liam Neeson and Daniel Day-Lewis. Depp was cast in July 1998 for his third collaboration with Burton. The actor wanted Ichabod to parallel Irving's description of the character in the short story. This included a long prosthetic snipe nose, huge ears, and elongated fingers. Paramount turned down his suggestions, and after Depp read Tom Stoppard's rewrite of the script, he was inspired to take the character even further. "I always thought of Ichabod as a very delicate, fragile person who was maybe a little too in touch with his feminine side, like a frightened little girl," Depp explained. He did not wish to portray the character as a typical action star would have, and instead took inspiration by Angela Lansbury's performance in "Death on the Nile". "It's good," Burton reasoned, "because I'm not the greatest action director in the world, and he's not the greatest action star." Depp modeled Ichabod's detective personality from Basil Rathbone in the 1939 "Sherlock Holmes" film series. He also studied Roddy McDowall's acting for additional influence. Burton added that "the idea was to try to find an elegance in action of the kind that Christopher Lee or Peter Cushing or Vincent Price had." Christina Ricci, who worked with producer Scott Rudin on "The Addams Family", was cast as Katrina Van Tassel. "Sleepy Hollow" also reunited Burton with Jeffrey Jones (from "Beetlejuice" and "Ed Wood") as Reverend Steenwyck, Christopher Walken (Max Shreck in "Batman Returns") as the Hessian Horseman, Martin Landau ("Ed Wood") in a cameo role, and Hammer veteran Michael Gough (Alfred in Burton's "Batman" films), whom Burton tempted out of retirement. The Hammer influence was further confirmed by the casting of Christopher Lee in a small role as the Burgomaster who sends Crane to Sleepy Hollow.
BULLET::::- Constable Ichabod Crane serves as the protagonist in the 1999 film adaptation of "Sleepy Hollow", directed by Tim Burton and starring Johnny Depp. In this interpretation, he is a New York City policeman with an interest in Forensic science sent to Sleepy Hollow to investigate a series of grisly murders to prove the merits of his style of the investigation after he argues against the police's current methods. As in the original story, his horse is named Gunpowder. Ichabod's most notable traits in the movie include an ahead-of-his-time liking for post-mortem examinations, deduction, and scientific methods, as well as his being very quirky, skittish, and being disturbed by death and blood, despite his occupation. His backstory is also explored: when he was seven his mother, an "innocent child of Nature" was "murdered to save her soul" by his father, "a Bible black tyrant behind a mask of righteousness" which led to a loss of faith for him. It is Ichabod who finally releases the Hessian Headless Horseman (Christopher Walken) from the control of Lady van Tassel (Miranda Richardson), whom the Horseman takes to Hell with him. Katrina Van Tassel (Christina Ricci) is seen at the end of the movie going back to New York with Ichabod, along with a boy who helped him in the investigation. Brom Bones (Casper Van Dien), who at one point does disguise himself as the Horseman and throws a pumpkin at Ichabod, is killed by the real Horseman halfway in the film.
Depp's next venture with Burton was the period film "Sleepy Hollow" (1999), in which he played Ichabod Crane opposite Christina Ricci and Christopher Walken. For his performance, Depp took inspiration from Angela Lansbury, Roddy McDowall and Basil Rathbone. He stated that he "always thought of Ichabod as a very delicate, fragile person who was maybe a little too in touch with his feminine side, like a frightened little girl."
BULLET::::- Ichabod Crane is also featured in the 2013 episodic video game, "The Wolf Among Us", developed and produced by Telltale Games. In the game, Crane (voiced by Roger L. Jackson) is the deputy mayor of Fabletown, a secret community of magical, fairytale beings who were exiled from their Homelands centuries ago and forced to live in the world of mundane humans. In episodes 2 through three, Crane was revealed to have been soliciting prostitutes and using a magic spell to make them look like his assistant Snow White; Sheriff Bigby Wolf and Snow arrest Crane for this and embezzling Fabletown's money to pay for them, but Crane is then kidnapped by the minions of the Crooked Man, the crime lord Crane owes money to.
